The Earl of Balfour, L.G..0.M.,fir M.P.A. Hankey, G.C.BSeoretary. THE GENEVA l. The Cabinet had before them the followingPROTOCOLAND SECURITY, documents in regard to the Geneva Protocol and thequestion of British, Blench and Belgian security:-(previous reference: A Memorandum by the Chairman of theCabinet 7 Committee of Imperial Defence(25), Con- (Paper CP.-105 (25)), with theolusion 20). following enclosures:-(i) report^t of Sub-Committee(CI.D. Paper No.559-B),(ii) Draft Letter to Secretary-General,League of Nations (C.I.D. PaperNO.S89-B),(iii) Minutes of 190th, 192nd, 195thand 196th Meetings of the Committeeof Imperial Defence.X A Note by the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs, covering a memorandum prepared in the Foreign Office (paper cp.-106 (25)).A Note by the Secretary of State forIndia, covering Telegram from theGovernment of India (Paper CP.-Ill(25)).A Memorandum by Lord Cecil (Paper G.P.-112 (25)),A Memorandum by the Secretary of Statefor War, covering a Memorandum by theGeneral Staff (Paper CP.-116 (25).A Memorandum by the Chancellor of theExchequer (Paper CP.-118 (25)).A Memorandum by the Secretar:/ of Statefor Air (Paper CP.-121 (25)).x A Memorandum by the Secretary of State' for Foreign Affairs (Paper CP.-122 (25)).After reviewing all aspects of the abovequestions, the Cabinet agreed -r(a) To accept the view of the Committeeof Imperial Defence, which is con-firmed by the reports so far receivedfrom the Dominions and India, thatthe Geneva Protocol is open to , graveobjection and cannot be accepted:lb) That a reply to the League in theform of a,simple rejection of the protocol, without any attempt topave the way to some alternative plan in regard to the vital questionof national security, is to be deprecated as calculated to prolongthe present state of insecurity andtension in Europe which It is the aim of His Majesty1 s Government to allay:(c) That, with a view to the furtherconsideration of the alternative policy to be adopted, the following documents should he drawn up beforethe next Meeting of the Cabinet * onWednesday March 4th:-(i) By the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs: On the basisof a rough' draft prepared duringthe Meeting (Appendix)which represented the general trend of the Cabinet's view, a formula which Mr Austen Chamberlain could use in his forthcoming aonversa-tions with M. Her riot ""in Pariswhile en route to Geneva, as ageneraX""guide (sub ject to reason-able latitude for purposes of negotiation) on the question of \security, or, if he should sodesire, as an aide-memoire tobe handed to MTTIerrlot:(ii) By the Earl of Balfour, in oonoertwith" the "Foreign Secretary: A revise of^he draft despatch to the League,giving reasons for the rejection of the Protocol (C.I.D. Paper589-B), in order to attune it tothe policy suggested in theAppendix, and with a view to its being" read by the Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs at theforthcoming meeting of the Councilof the League and publishedsimultaneously in this country:(iii) By the Seoretary of State for theppl^nes:A telegram or telegrams to "the""'Dominions, notifying them,of the action which it' was nowproposed to take, and Communication-cating a summary or the text ofsuch documents as he might deemdesirable:(d) That the Lord President of the Council,in replying' to a Question to be asked by Lord Parmoor in the House of lords on Tuesday, March 3rd, should indicate the probability that papers would bepublished in the near future, and should,as far as possible, avoid giving any indication at this stage of the "trend of the Government^ polIc7/-; (e) That the Committee of ImperialDefence should examine themilitary aspects of a quadri-lateral agreement between "ranee,G-ermany, Great Britain and Belgium,as suggested lib. the Appendix.-3- fl&APORE.eviousiferenoe:cabinet 25) , Oon-us ion 6. )2, The Cabinet approved a Menlo'randuia/by ,the Chairman of the Commitiiee A imperialDefence (Paper CP. -124 (2S)) i the prin-cipal recommendations of which vrere:^That the site for a floating dock at singapore should be in the Old Strait,as proposed "by the Admiralty and approved in 1922 by the Committee of ImperialDefence;That the site for the aerodrome andseaplane station should be on theSouth shore of the Old Strait, as previously approved; aridThat the programme of work for the nextfew years should be as follows:- poripticii of Works. ' i 204,000 306,000 277,000 787,000.... 2, Whitehall Gardens,. S.W.1,March 2 , 1925. APPENDIX.ROUGH DRAFT FORMULA ON SECURITY.His Majesty1s Government do not feel able toenter into a dual Paot with. France with or withoutBelgium. The question of a quadrilateral agreementbetween France, Germany, Great Britain, belgium and, if possible, with the accord of Italy, for mutual securityfand for guaranteeing each other'sfrontiers in the West of Europ^, stands on a different footing and might become a great assurance to thepeace of Europe and lead to a rapid reduction ofarmaments. His Majesty1s Government have, of course,in these matters to carry with them the assent, or atleast the good will, of the various self-governingDominions of the British Empire. If the FrenchGovernment share the views of His Majesty1 s Governmentand will regulate their action towards Germanyaccordingly, His Majesty1s Government will, fortheir part, begin the necessary discussions with theDominions, and in all their policy will endeavour tofurther the common cause.
